newsitem.title: IRAQ: Iraq asks U.N. to increase partial oil sales.
newsitem.headline: Iraq asks U.N. to increase partial oil sales.

text.p: Iraq is holding talks with the United Nations to allow it an increase in the income from its oil-for-food deal with the United Nations, Oil Minister Amir Muhammad Rasheed said on Friday.

U.N. resolution 986 allows Baghdad $2 billion worth of oil exports over six months to offset the impact of U.N. sanctions imposed after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990. It went into effect on December 10 last year.

"Under 986 the U.N. Secretary-General (Kofi Annan) is to prepare a report after 90 days (of implementation), that is two weeks from now, suggesting an increase in the money which is $1 billion," Rasheed told a news conference.
Rasheed said Iraqi Foreign Minister Mohammed Saeed al-Sahaf was in New York to raise the issue with Annan. "We are asking it should be a very good increase," he said.

He said out of $1 billion worth of exports Iraq is allowed to pump to the outside world over the first 90 days Iraq's share would be $660 million "which is not enough to meet the very miniumum basic needs of its people".
Some 30 per cent of Iraq's oil money goes to a U.N. fund to compensate the victims of Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait. Iraq has also to meet other U.N. costs.
Rasheed said the value of Iraq's partial oil exports under the U.N. deal had reached $864 million on Thursday.
"And until March 13 we hope to export what will be worth $1.70 billion," Rasheed said.

He said that on Thursday Iraq $611 million in its escrow account in New York. He said about $400 million would remain for Iraq after deducting 30 per cent for the 1991 Gulf War reparations and other U.N. costs.
